content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

I see multiple fragments of tissue stained with H&E. Most of these appear to be lymph nodes, embedded in adipose (fat) tissue. There are approximately 8 distinct lymph nodes visible. They vary in size and some show a uniformly dense blue appearance, while others appear more mottled or have lighter pink areas, which warrants closer inspection for potential metastasis in a colorectal cancer case.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

As a pathologist, my task is to systematically examine every lymph node for evidence of metastasis. The green box is placed on one of the larger lymph nodes in the center of the slide. I am zooming into the periphery of the lymphoid tissue, near the capsule and subcapsular sinus. This is a critical area to inspect because metastatic tumor cells arriving via lymphatic vessels typically first deposit and grow in this subcapsular region. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, the standard procedure for staging colorectal cancer involves examining every lymph node submitted. The area indicated by the green box is one of these potential lymph nodes, located in the lower right portion of the slide. I am zooming in to meticulously inspect its architecture and cellular composition to determine if it is a benign (negative) lymph node or if it contains metastatic tumor cells (positive node). I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my approach is to examine every lymph node thoroughly. The zoomed-in area, indicated by the green box, is on one of the lymph nodes located in the upper right of the slide. I would zoom into this area as part of a systematic review of all submitted lymph nodes. The purpose of zooming in is to assess the lymph node architecture and cellular detail at high magnification, which is essential for detecting small metastatic deposits, isolated tumor cells, or subtle architectural effacement that might not be visible at low power. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. This is the third lymph node section from the top on the left side. I am zooming into this specific area at the periphery of the lymph node because this is the subcapsular sinus region. This is the most common location for the initial arrival and deposit of metastatic tumor cells. At low power, this part of the node appears more densely purple and architecturally disrupted compared to the rest of the lymphoid tissue, which is suspicious for a metastatic focus. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this area because it is located within a lymph node (the large one in the bottom right quadrant) that shows some architectural abnormalities even at low power. The green box is placed over the periphery of the lymphoid tissue, near the subcapsular sinus, which is a classic location for early metastatic deposits to arrive. The area appears somewhat disorganized and heterogeneous in color compared to the more uniform purple of other lymphoid areas, raising suspicion for infiltration by non-lymphoid cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would systematically examine every lymph node on the slide. The green box highlights a specific area within one of the smaller lymph nodes in the lower right quadrant. This area corresponds to the hilum of the lymph node, which is the region where blood vessels and lymphatic channels enter and exit. At low power, this hilar area appears somewhat disorganized and more eosinophilic (pink) compared to the surrounding dense lymphoid tissue. The hilum and the subcapsular sinus are the most common initial sites for metastatic tumor cells to lodge. Therefore, any subtle architectural or cytologic abnormality in this region requires high-magnification review to rule out micrometastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see the edge of a lymph node. There is a dense population of small, dark, round cells, which are lymphocytes. Interspersed within the lymphoid tissue, particularly towards the top of the image near the fibrous capsule, there are numerous macrophages (histiocytes) containing coarse, brown-black pigment (likely anthracotic pigment or hemosiderin). The sinusoids (lymphatic channels within the node) appear expanded and filled with these histiocytes, a feature known as sinus histiocytosis. I do not see any definite nests of atypical epithelial cells, abnormal gland formation, or other features of metastatic adenocarcinoma in this specific field. My impression for this area is a reactive lymph node with prominent sinus histiocytosis and pigment deposition, with no evidence of malignancy in this view.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see a section of a lymph node. The tissue is densely populated by small, dark-staining lymphocytes, forming some vague nodular structures (follicles). There are also numerous scattered histiocytes containing coarse, dark brown pigment, likely hemosiderin. A prominent feature is the presence of irregularly shaped, bright pink, acellular structures, which represent hyalinized or sclerotic blood vessels. I do not see any definite clusters, nests, or glands formed by atypical epithelial cells. Therefore, my impression is that this is a benign, reactive lymph node, likely negative for metastasis. The findings of vascular hyalinization and pigment deposition are common and non-neoplastic.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see a dense population of small, mature-appearing lymphocytes, consistent with lymphoid tissue. There are also several open channels, which are the sinuses of the lymph node. A prominent feature is the presence of numerous macrophages containing coarse, brown-black pigment (melanophages), a condition known as melanosis. There are no clear, atypical glandular structures, clusters of malignant cells, or signet-ring cells to suggest metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression of this specific field is a reactive lymph node with sinus histiocytosis and prominent melanosis. It is negative for malignancy in this view, but the entire node and all other nodes must be examined to render a final diagnosis.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see the lymph node capsule and surrounding fat on the lower left. The upper portion of the image shows lymphoid tissue with reactive follicles. Critically, located within the subcapsular and cortical sinuses, there are nests and clusters of atypical cells that are clearly non-lymphoid. These cells have larger, irregular nuclei, more abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, and are forming poorly defined glandular structures. There are also macrophages containing brown pigment (hemosiderin). My impression is that this is metastatic adenocarcinoma, confirming this is a positive lymph node.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I can see the capsule of the lymph node and adjacent adipose tissue on the left. The main field shows lymph node parenchyma that is heavily infiltrated. There is a background population of small, dark lymphocytes. However, there are numerous clusters and poorly-formed glands composed of atypical epithelial cells. These cells are much larger than the surrounding lymphocytes, with abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, large pleomorphic nuclei, and prominent nucleoli. There are also scattered macrophages containing brown pigment (hemosiderin or lipofuscin). My impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic adenocarcinoma, consistent with an origin from a colorectal primary.
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I see the hilar structures of the lymph node. There are several large, thick-walled blood vessels (arteries and veins) and some lymphatic spaces, set within a fibrotic stroma. There is a dense infiltrate of cells, which on closer inspection consists of mature lymphocytes, plasma cells, and numerous large histiocytes (macrophages) containing coarse, dark brown/black pigment. This pigment is likely hemosiderin (from old hemorrhage) or anthracotic pigment. This finding is characteristic of sinus histiocytosis with pigment deposition. I do not see any atypical epithelial cells, abnormal glands, or cohesive nests of tumor cells. My impression of this specific field is that it represents reactive changes within the lymph node hilum, not metastatic carcinoma.
